title-group.article-title: Rising damp in walls: Evaluation of the level achieved by the damp front

contrib-group.aff: Laboratório de Física das Construções (LFC), Departamento de Engenharia Civil, Faculdade de Engenharia da Universidade do Porto, Portugal

author-notes.corresp: Ana S Guimarães, Laboratório de Física das Construções (LFC), Departamento de Engenharia Civil, Faculdade de Engenharia da Universidade do Porto, Rua Dr. Roberto Frias, s/n, Porto 4200-465, Portugal. Email: anasofia@fe.up.pt

abstract.p: Treating rising damp in the walls of historical buildings is complex because moisture transfer into the walls of old buildings in direct contact with the ground leads to the migration of soluble salts. This work analyzes rising damp using concepts and methods of unsaturated moisture flow theory, and a numerical validation study. A simple analytical model describes the rising damp front for the simplified situation of a monolithic wall. The influence of wall thickness, boundary conditions, wall composition, and material properties, such as porosity and sorptivity, are analyzed in detail.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Rising damp, a worldwide phenomenon, is a major cause of decay in masonry materials such as stone, brick, and mortar. Rising damp in historical buildings may be considered one of the most important of all the different manifestations of moisture, leading to the decay of stone materials by freeze–thaw cycles in the presence of salts (in many cases increased salt content is associated with rising damp, as shown by Künzel, 1995); decay of elements in contact with the stone walls, such as wooden beams, wooden ceilings, and other finishings; and poor sanitary conditions caused by the development of fungus and mold.

The treatment of rising damp in historical buildings walls is complex, particularly for thick walls that are built with different materials. The traditional techniques, such as waterproof barriers, injection of hydrofuge products, and so on, sometimes are ineffective or expensive, justifying the need to find new approaches (see Guimarães et al., 2010).

The Building Physics Laboratory (Laboratório de Física das Construções (LFC)) at the University of Porto Faculty of Engineering (Faculdade de Engenharia da Universidade do Porto (FEUP)) has been performing research on the problems of rising damp. This article presents an analytical study of the phenomenon of rising damp (sharp front theory for capillary absorption) developed by Hall and his team (Gummerson et al., 1980; Hall, 1977, 1981; Hall and Hoff, 2002, 2007; Hall et al., 1984), based on the theory of unsaturated flow, together with the numerical results, using WUFI 2D v.3.3, that validate the analytical predictions for steady-state height of rise. An analytical solution, though it does not provide an exact representation of the physical phenomenon, is very simple, and it provides predictions consistent with practical observations.

Historical buildings in Portugal may, in fact, contain walls that are up to 1 m thick, built from various different materials (e.g., limestone in the center, marble in the south, and granite in the north of the country). This article presents the results of our study, which consisted of a large number of numerical simulations on walls composed of different materials (granite and limestone), used to validate the analytical solution developed by Hall and his team. The main goal is to estimate the level achieved by the damp front in steady state. To estimate the height of the rising damp front, h∞, it is necessary to improve the treatment techniques.

sec.title: Capillary absorption
sec.p: Capillary suction is a fundamental transport mechanism to describe the water absorption in porous building materials. Furthermore, to describe this type of transport, it is important to measure the penetration depth and the absorbed water amount as a function of time. The amount of absorbed water can be determined easily by measuring the increase in weight of the test specimen as function of time. The determination of the penetration depth is more difficult.

Equation (1) is well known as the Lucas–Washbum equation, describing the horizontal movement of the meniscus and can be applied to the vertical movement when neglecting the contribution given by the weight of water. It is also called in literature as the square root of time law, where k is the capillarity coefficient that covers the relationship between the pore structure and movement of liquid phase.

sec.title: Configurations tested
sec.p: Rising damp may usually be controlled by adopting one or more of the following treatment techniques as (Freitas et al., 2011):

list-item.p: Adopting physical or chemical barrier, by reducing the absorbent section;
Creating electric potential and installing Knappen drainage;
Hiding anomalies behind a new built wall;

sec.p: In the analysis presented in this study, we selected the last two techniques, concealing wall anomalies and ventilating the wall base. The latter technique consists of ventilating the wall’s base through the installation of a hygro-regulable mechanical ventilation device. Ventilation of the wall’s base increases evaporation, which leads to a reduction in the level achieved by the damp front. This is possible only when the groundwater is lower than the base of the wall.

sec.title: Numerical simulation
sec.p: Simulation programs that evaluate changes in the moisture content and temperature inside walls are essential tools for simulating the behavior of walls in the presence of moisture dependent on internal and external climatic conditions (Bomberg, 1974).

The calculation program used in the numerical simulations for the experimental and analytical validations was WUFI 2D v.2.1, developed by the Fraunhofer Institute for Building Physics. The governing equation for moisture transport is (Holm and Kunzel, 2003; Kalamees et al., 2006)
and the governing equation for heat transport is

where dH/dT is the heat storage capacity of the moist building material, dw/d; is the moisture storage capacity, λT is the thermal conductivity, D is the liquid conduction coefficient, δp is the water vapor permeability, hv is the evaporation enthalpy of the water, pa is the water vapor saturation pressure, T is the temperature, and is the relative humidity (Evrard and De Herde, 2010).
In the numerical analysis used to validate the analytical study, only the change in relative humidity was considered important, since the experiments took place under isothermal conditions.

Hygrothermal modeling offers a powerful tool for predicting heat and moisture transport through multilayer building assemblies. In this work, the hygrothermal model was used to compare the results of the three configurations (see Figure 2), with two types of monolithic walls, with different wall thicknesses, and under different natural conditions. The simulations used two different climates, a controlled laboratory climate and the others with real climatic variables of Porto city, and actual material properties to determine the height of the rising damp front (see Table 1).

The numerical simulations, with real climate, were made using climate data for Porto provided by a software tool (METEOTEST, 2008). This program calculates the hourly values for all parameters using a stochastic model, and the resulting weather data files are produced in a variety of formats. The weather data used as input for the model were temperature (°C), relative humidity (%), precipitation (mm/h), and global solar radiation on a horizontal surface (W/m2). The short-wave radiation absorptivity and long-wave radiation emissivity considered were 0.4 and 0.9, respectively, and the initial conditions within the element were = 80% and T = 20°C.
The other numerical simulations used the climatic conditions inside the laboratory. The temperature and relative humidity were considered constant, 20°C and 60%, respectively.

The vapor diffusion thickness value used was 0 (no coating), and the interior heat transfer coefficient was constant and equal to 8 W/m2 K. The exterior heat transfer coefficient only contained the convective element and was considered independent of wind (at a constant value of 17 W/m2 K).

sec.p: The results presented in Tables 2 and 3 show that the simple analytical model proposed by Hall et al. (1984) clearly describes the rising damp front when compared with the numerical simulations, which provide a qualitative validation of equations (28) and (29).

The results, also, show that with a controlled climate (in laboratory), the similarities between the numerical and analytical results were better (with a relative error of approximately 8.3%, in average) when compared with the results obtained with a real climate (with a relative error of approximately 19.6%, in average). This is an expected result considering the influence of several climate variables in the numerical simulation, as radiation, precipitation, temperature, wind velocity, and direction, throughout the year, and taking into account that in the analytical analysis (equations (28) and (29)) the evaporation potential considered was an annual average.

sec.title: Analysis of several properties that influence rising damp phenomenon
sec.p: Tables 2 and 3 show that rising damp increases when drying conditions are hampered by extra waterproof coatings (see results obtained with Configurations 1 and 2). This result shows that the traditional techniques of applying coatings with reduced porosity or hiding anomalies behind a new built wall cannot be used as efficient techniques to treat rising damp. In addition, the presence of a wall base ventilation system on both sides entails a reduction of the damp front (Configuration 3).

The numerical results presented in Tables 2 and 3, also, show that the steady-state heights of rise, h∞, obtained in laboratory conditions, were highest, when compared with the results obtained with the Porto climate. This is an expected result if we have in mind that, in laboratorial conditions, we have no solar radiation and lower values of evaporation potential.

Related to the material properties, limestone presented a higher capillary ascension and granite presented a lower capillary ascension. This difference is explained by the fact that rising damp increases in materials with higher sorptivity (

sec.title: Critical review
sec.p: The Lucas–Washbum equation, equation (1), is based on a single pipe model representing the porous media and cannot accurately model a complex capillary system of a porous material. Furthermore, the rate of capillary absorption will depend on the degree of porous medium saturation.

In conclusion, the analytical model, presented by Hall and Hoff (2002) and based on Lucas–Washbum equation, describes in a simplified form the steady-state mass balance between the capillary water absorption rate and the evaporation rate. Furthermore, the model used in this work does not account for the effects of salt migration and buildup on moisture transport.

Another important variable that needs to be considered in the rising damp analyses is the local evaporation potential. A correct value of this variable is difficult to establish as it depends on several meteorological conditions, such as temperature, relative humidity, air velocity, precipitation, solar radiation, and so on. In this study, the data used as boundary conditions in the internal and external surfaces of the analyzed building element were selected for a “reference year.” There is concern with using reference years that were established for the annual energy predictions. The need of weather data reference years for building simulations has been recognized, and many different methods have been developed (Hensen, 1999).

Another important source of errors relates to material properties, such as the sorptivity, S, that can be difficult to obtain. This and other properties have been measured for different materials, including stone, brick, mortar, and plaster. However, for the masonry walls, the sorptivity may be lower than the masonry units because of the joints and interfaces. Freitas et al. (1996) stated that “the interface between layers generally causes an acceleration of drying outer layer by lack of moisture feeding” and “the interface between layers slows the imbibitions process in a way much more pronounced the smaller the maximum flow transmitted. This stream translates the water resistance between contact layers.”

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: The main conclusions of this study are as follows:

list-item.p: “Wall base ventilation system” design model highlighted significance of some important and simple parameters such as the evaporation potential inside the system, es.

The simple analytical model, based on “sharp front” theory, predicts values for the steady height of rise that are consistent with the numerical results, which provide a qualitative validation of the analytical model.

The comparison between the numerical results and the analytical solutions shows better agreement for laboratorial conditions and for a limestone wall, than for real climates (Porto city) and granite wall.
The evaporation potential, e, is an important parameter to be in consideration, and the analytical results obtained were better in interior climates, as e is more stable.

Regarding the influence of material properties, the most important parameter is the absorption coefficient of water, which was as expected, since this parameter best characterizes the movement of water in liquid phase within construction materials.
The results obtained, also, show that the steady-state height of rise increases with the wall thickness as a function of the square root of the thickness.
The use of tiles (Configuration 2) presents as a bad solution to treat rising damp because the tiles reduce the evaporation area and the level achieved by the damp front increases.
